Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Separations with molecularly thin silicon membranes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1159579
McGrath

This NSF award by the Chemical and Biological Separations program supports work by Professors James McGrath and Philippe M Fauchet focused on development and application of porous nanocrystalline silicon (pnc-Si). Pnc-Si is a silicon-based nanoporous membrane that is more than 1000 times thinner than conventional membrane materials used in filtration and separation processes. The thinness of the membrane endows it with extraordinary permeability and enables high resolution separations in both convective and diffusive transport. Combined with the manufacturability afforded by the silicon manufacturing process, pnc-Si membranes represent an important new membrane platform with a wide range of uses in sensors, lab-on-a-chip systems, and biomedical devices. The work under this funding will elucidate the basic relationships between membrane structure and performance in separation processes. Manufacturing methods will tune pore sizes and other membrane properties so that the membranes are optimized for particular separations involving proteins, DNA, and nanoparticles. The ultimate goal of the proposal is an analytical and/or computational model that can predict sieving performance based on the physiochemical properties of the membrane, the solute, and the method of filtration. The results will allow the rational use pnc-Si and other ultrathin membranes for new devices such as miniaturized pathogen detectors and wearable hemodialysis systems.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: This project developed both a theoretical and practical understanding of normal flow separations with ultrathin (50 nm thick) silicon membranes (nanomembranes). While nanomembranes are known to exhibit both high resolution separations and high permeability, little work has been done to elucidate the mechanisms of sieving in convective flows. The project supported the development of a new type of nanomembrane (nanoporous silicon nitride; NPN) with more robust mechanical and chemical stability than the original pure silicon versions (pnc-Si).  These membranes were then used to develop predictive models of both fouling and sieving.

Broader Impacts: The designation of this project as a GOALI grant enabled unique training opportuinities for both a post-doc and a graduate student at the partner company SiMPore Inc. The post-doc actually performed an internship at SiMPore while the graduate student was able to shadow the manufacturing team for several weeks. The project also supported training of two undergraduates. Because of SiMPore's involvement in group meetings, all trainees were educated about the commercial need for high resolution separations. While the project focused on basic science of ultrathin membrane separations, it can be directly credited with a recent successful NIH Phase I STTR award to build separation devices based on NPN and with a NSF STTR Phase I award on using NPN for hemodialysis. 

The primary outcomes of this proposal are the following: 

  1. The development of Nanoporous Nitride (NPN) nanomembranes. These membranes, now made in 50 - 100 nm varieties, are more permeabile, and more robust than the original pure silicon nanomembranes. Results are documented in our publication: DesOrmeaux, et al. (2014) Nanoscale. 20146:10798-10805. See Figure 1. 
  2. Mechanisms of nanomembrane fouling and capacity determination. In this effort we conducted studies to elucidate the role of particle concentration and sizes on the fouling and filtration capacity of nanomembranes. Both mathematical modeling and physical evidence suggests that cake formation is the primary mode of fouling for nanomembranes used in dead end filtration (See Figure 2).  Results are documented in our publication: Winans, et al., (2016)  J. Mem. Sci. 499: 282-289 
  3. Predictive model of sieving by nanomembranes. In this work we developed a mathematical model that predicts the abilty of nanoembranes to discriminate between similarly sized particles. Importantly, we discovered that the resolution of separations is pressure dependent. The key benefit of ultrathin membranes appears to be their ability to exhibit optimal resolution at low pressures (Figure 3). Our model also revealed that the extent to which the polydispersity of pore sizes is limiting the resolution of NPN. Results will be published in a forthcoming paper.

Modified by: James L Mcgrath

While nanomembranes are known to exhibit both high resolution separations and high permeability, little work has been done to elucidate the mechanisms of sieving in convective flows. These membranes were then used to develop predictive models of both fouling and sieving. While the project focused on basic science of ultrathin membrane separations, it can be directly credited with a recent successful NIH Phase I STTR award to build separation devices based on NPN and with a NSF STTR Phase I award on using NPN for hemodialysis. The primary outcomes of this proposal are the following: The development of Nanoporous Nitride (NPN) nanomembranes. (2014) Nanoscale. 20146:10798-10805. See Figure 1. Mechanisms of nanomembrane fouling and capacity determination. In this effort we conducted studies to elucidate the role of particle concentration and sizes on the fouling and filtration capacity of nanomembranes. Both mathematical modeling and physical evidence suggests that cake formation is the primary mode of fouling for nanomembranes used in dead end filtration (See Figure 2). Results are documented in our publication: Winans, et al., (2016) J. Mem. Sci. 499: 282-289 Predictive model of sieving by nanomembranes. In this work we developed a mathematical model that predicts the abilty of nanoembranes to discriminate between similarly sized particles. Importantly, we discovered that the resolution of separations is pressure dependent. The key benefit of ultrathin membranes appears to be their ability to exhibit optimal resolution at low pressures (Figure 3). Our model also revealed that the extent to which the polydispersity of pore sizes is limiting the resolution of NPN. Results will be published in a forthcoming paper.
